newsitem.title: USA: Merrill Lynch analyst upbeat about Hong Kong.
newsitem.headline: Merrill Lynch analyst upbeat about Hong Kong.

text.p: Foreign investors should continue using Hong Kong as a proxy for investing in China -- now and after 1997, said Merrill Lynch political analyst Richard Margolis.

The separation of foreign investors from domestic investors in A-share and B-share markets in China poses a difficult problem that is best avoided by investing in the liquid Hong Kong Hang Seng stock index, Margolis, who is based in Hong Kong, told a press luncheon here.
"The Hang Seng index demonstrates a good correlation to China's economic policy," he said.
"You can buy an orthodox portfolio of Hang Seng index constituent stocks and gain sensible exposure to China."
The strong performance of the Hang Seng index over the past five months reflected the successful soft landing of China's overheating economy.
Hong Kong's transition to Chinese sovereignty in 1997 will not signficantly alter its long-standing symbiotic relationship with China, or its political risk profile.
"We remain basically positive on the Hang Seng index through the transition," he said.
Margolis considered Taiwan, rather than Singapore or Shanghai to be the main competition for Hong Kong in the future.

"As an exporter of capital, a source of entrepreneurial skills and an effective manager and developer of China's cost advantages, Taiwan likely has the ability to match Hong Kong across the board," he said.
